45451.base_text:
This land like a mirror turns you inward
And you become a forest in a furtive lake;
The dark pines of your mind reach downward,
You dream in the green of your time,
Your memory is a row of sinking pines.

variants.text:
This land like a mirror turns you inward
And you become a forest in a furtive lake;
The dark pines of your mind reach downward,
You dream in the green of your time,
Your memory is a row of sinking pines.

45451.base_text: I’m not sure how to tell you this, Niko. I don’t want to gut you, reach inside and pull things out, not again. Some tales, I guess, are better left untold. And you’ve already heard this one, even if your version never quite matched mine.
But that’s what writing this is for. If it’s just a story, nothing else, maybe we can understand, come to terms.

I don’t think I ever told this to you. When I was little, my dad used to come tuck me in at night, and sometimes I’d blink and he’d disappear. He’d be sitting on my bed, singing or smoothing my sheets or telling a story, warm and alive, and between one blink and the next he’d be gone. My heart would thump and I’d clutch the blanket, terrified, eyes thrashing back and forth across the dark spaces of my room like a trapped bird looking for a way out, looking for him, but he’d be gone, and I’d be alone.

variants.text: I don’t think I ever told this to you. When I was little, my dad used to come tuck me in at night, and sometimes I’d blink and he’d disappear. He’d be sitting on my bed, singing or smoothing my sheets or telling a story, warm and alive, and between one blink and the next he’d be gone. My heart would thump and I’d clutch the blanket, terrified, eyes thrashing back and forth across the dark spaces of my room like a trapped bird looking for a way out, looking for him, but he’d be gone, and I’d be alone.

45451.base_text: Maybe premonition. More likely was that I’d fall asleep, waiting for him to come in, and dream he had. Some noise would jerk me up to a room where he’d long since looked in on me and pulled the door gently shut. But how I rationalize it makes no difference. It doesn’t change how I lived that loss, each night it happened. How I can feel it even today. The person who loved me most, erased from existence in a blink. I’ll never forget how that felt. Even if it never really happened.

Some noise would jerk me up to a room where he’d long since looked in on me and pulled the door gently shut. But how I rationalize it makes no difference. It doesn’t change how I lived that loss, each night it happened. How I can feel it even today. The person who loved me most, erased from existence in a blink. I’ll never forget how that felt. Even if it never really happened.

45451.base_text: But this story. Our story. Maybe it’s a language we can speak, you and I. Find in the telling the truths that matter. Embellish, revise. Excise. Revision.

variants.text: But this story. Our story. Maybe it’s a language we can speak, you and I. Find in the telling the truths that matter. Embellish, revise. Excise. Revision.

45451.base_text: Although our story actually happened. You know that, don’t you?

variants.text: Although our story actually happened. You know that, don’t you?

45451.base_text: This is what happened when we found a hidden staircase underneath my bed, and decided to find out where it led.

This land like a mirror turns you inward

45452.base_text: I’m not sure how to tell you this. I don’t want to gut you, reach inside and pull things out, not again. Old wounds and sleeping dogs, you know. Tales better left untold. And you’ve already heard this one, even if your story wasn’t quite the same as mine.
But that’s what writing this is for. If it’s only a story, maybe we can understand it. You know, make peace. Pretend it’s not ours.

45452.base_text: Okay, so. Here goes. You ready?

45462.base_text:
I am not yours, not lost in you,
Not lost, although I long to be
Lost as a candle lit at noon,
Lost as a snowflake in the sea.

variants.text:

Not lost, although I long to be

Lost as a snowflake in the sea.

45462.base_text: I can’t tell you this. I don’t want to gut you, reach inside and pull things out, not again. Old wounds and sleeping dogs, you know. Tales better left untold. And you’ve heard this one before, even if our stories were never quite the same.
But that’s what writing this is for. If it’s a story, you see, maybe we can understand, make peace.

Here’s a story I don’t think you ever heard. In sixth grade I had a brief friendship with a weird, indrawn kid with the same unhealthy imagination as me. He liked to possible. When you catch something from the corner of your eye, he’d explained, and it looks for an instant like something fantastic—a witch’s face in a hedge, a huge monstrous far-off thing instead of a tiny nearby insect—instead of correcting your perceptions, you let yourself keep believing in that first impression for as long as you can. You possible it. Hold it in your head, your mental model of what’s real. Keep your mind from asserting the boring truth it thinks it knows and trust the one your senses first perceived. And I’d tried this, with him and on my own, off and on for a few weeks until I scared myself because I was getting too good at it. So was he: I realized it before long when he started scaring me with stories about the things he’d seen, and I think his parents or the school figured it out not long after, because they took him away and I got sent to a counselor for a few weeks just for being friends with him.

When you catch something from the corner of your eye, he’d explained, and it looks for an instant like something fantastic—a witch’s face in a hedge, a huge monstrous far-off thing instead of a tiny nearby insect—instead of correcting your perceptions, you let yourself keep believing in that first impression for as long as you can. You possible it. Hold it in your head, your mental model of what’s real. Keep your mind from asserting the boring truth it thinks it knows and trust the one your senses first perceived. And I’d tried this, with him and on my own, off and on for a few weeks until I scared myself because I was getting too good at it. So was he: I realized it before long when he started scaring me with stories about the things he’d seen, and I think his parents or the school figured it out not long after, because they took him away and I got sent to a counselor for a few weeks just for being friends with him.

45462.base_text: But you don’t unlearn something like that. Not completely. I’d become an expert at seeing things that weren’t there. Useful, sometimes, but usually, usually…

variants.text: But you don’t unlearn something like that. Not completely. I’d become an expert at seeing things that weren’t there. Useful, sometimes, but usually, usually…

45462.base_text: But it taught me an important lesson. Just because something isn’t real doesn’t mean it can’t hurt you. I’ll never forget some of the things I possibled, even if they never really happened. There’s truth in first impressions, in fleeting visions, even if it’s not the kind we’re trained to trust. Stories make shapes, build structure out of shadows: calcified shells that linger long after muddled innards fade. They’re not the real thing, as gloriously as they pretend to be. But still. Sometimes they’re enough.

45462.base_text: Although our story was never just a story. It happened. You know that, don’t you?
This is what happened when we found the stairs underneath my bed, and took them all the way down.
